we see this as we look across the world at what different governments are adopting there are you can't just jump
right into broad adoption of cloud computing you can't just say hey you guys should all do this and then just go
ahead and do it there are a lot of steps that have to happen first so really what we've been seeing is there are those two
foundational pieces at the bottom that are the first steps that a government has to take in the U.S government they
did that quite some time ago we had a cloud first policy that was issued by the Office of Management budget we've
now seen that issued also in the UK we've seen it issued in parts of Canada in parts of Australia we've got people
sort of thinking about it in other parts of the world Singapore Japan is thinking about it as well
so there's a policy directive but then there's also a definition and I
take a little responsibility for the struggles here I worked for another a few other I.T companies before I came
here there's a lot of muddied waters about what it is that's a cloud so
really laying out what is cloud so that you know what it is that you're mandating when you say cloud first so
those two pieces go hand in hand because the policy doesn't really have any teeth until you've got a government definition
of what is cloud so in the US we've seen nist really take the lead on this and
other you know in other countries or other organizations doing that then once you do that you've got to figure out
what are the security and compliance requirements do you have data sovereignty laws do you have what kinds
of data needs to be in different categories just like I was talking about with the dod model you have to have that
definition and figure out what is required and what are you going to ask
your your uh your cloud computing provider to do and then you put a standard in place and you ask people to
meet it so that's what we've done in places around the world and you know we've got Assurance from our vice
president Teresa Carlson there is no bar that we are unwilling to meet so every time that somebody comes out with a new
standard we work to meet that standard so so far we've met standards we've been among the first to meet standards the
fedramp standard in the United States these DOD models also we just met a
standard in Singapore we also met another standard in Australia so anytime that that one of those security regimes
comes out we meet it and that but that's really required because if you don't have it laid out
you can't get there The Next Step really a challenge is procurement so we definitely have seen
this in the United States where I'd say this is about where we are or where we have been in the last six months or so
in the United States is starting to see acquisition officers
really start to understand how to acquire Cloud the forward-thinking
acquisition officers and it's in other places too where they have to get used to not specifying I need this amount of

know they're used to doing that where they're sort of laying out here's my order what will it cost and instead

Technologies go and change policies he actually got himself on a committee to rewrite the management mandate he

and the final one I'm going to talk to you about is the FDA so the FDA has
built a very significant new project called open FDA there were a number of

and identify what was going on and try to solve problems for Citizens but also

things including Mechanical Turk so they used Mechanical Turk to get all the data in
um they they actually found a way to do it with HIPAA compliance where they broke the data down into chunks so that

then they also brought all of that data in and figured out a way to put it all together into databases so that they
could um you know pull it together and find ways to identify patterns
in terms of that piece of ingesting the data they had 99.7 percent accuracy and
reduced their costs from 29 dollars per page to digitize it to 25 cents per page
so that was pretty significant and then in terms of how they were
bringing together those Adverse Events and and trying to identify what was you
know where were their causes of problems they had very interesting um use of social media that they're doing where

all right so I'm going to talk to you about uh JPL so the jet propulsion laboratory so the jet propulsion
laboratory is a part of NASA and it's operated by Caltech
uh it's got about 5 000 employees and uh they're based in California
and so that they one of the things they've done is they've sent 19 spacecraft going back to the two Voyager
spacecraft in the 70s space to collect data for us to analyze and so
part of that is the Mars exploration program and so they sent all these things out to Mars and their one of
those was the Mars Curiosity Rover so the Mars Curiosity were over landed in
late 2011 and they had a project where they wanted to live stream the landing
of the Rover so this was a technically challenging project and then they you
know for for a geek like me this is the fun stuff in the project so they were streaming NASA TV which is an HD
television stream they were expecting about a million viewers on the Stream and uh it needed to support you know all
your common playback devices so uh iOS you know Android uh flash streaming
HTML5 all that kind of stuff uh they're expecting about uh one megabyte a second
uh or one megabit a second per viewer so they knew about how much bandwidth they needed and it was a once in a lifetime
opportunity uh you know the landing is going to happen once and so everything had to work because uh you you can get a
do-over you can push the landing right so everything had to be in place and properly set up now they faced some
interesting challenges here so uh this is the stuff that's not so fun they
found out that so NASA obviously has a live streaming setup that they use and they found out that they couldn't use it
they found this out six days before the landing so they had no live stream set up for this uh curiosity over Landing
six days ahead of time uh now okay you know so you could provision some space and a constant delivery network no big
deal right well it was also the same week as the Olympics so what that means was there's a crunch on CDN capacity
across you know various providers so they couldn't just go out there and and uh buy capacity from a constant delivery
Network the other challenge they had was they had a really small team they had two people available to work on this and I
think there were about two people from Amazon that were also available to work in this so they had a really small team and they needed to get really big
results so let's talk about the technical problem or the technical challenge with
streaming video so the way video streams work is you know you have your video files and they're typically saved in
four megabytes segments that's fairly big file size um so you know you just keep adding
segments and then you have this file called a manifest file and that file is what tells your player in your web
browser which of those segments to play so once a video stream file the four
megabyte file has been put you know it has been written that's never going to change you just keep writing new files
as the live stream goes on the Manifest changes every four seconds because it it
tells your player hey I need to load the next segment so um the four megabyte file you can cache
right so you can you can cache it you can put on the CDN the little manifest file you can cache so that's that makes
you know or it's very difficult to Cache it so they designed a plan and this is you know what's really amazing because with
the Amazon web services in six days they planned the solution they executed on that solution this is something that
just wouldn't have been possible in Old World on premise infrastructure so they you know they did
some testing and they figured out uh that the origin so the origin is basically the server that the stream was
originating from so there's a laptop like this and that has the actual stream plugged into it and the laptop is
sending that video up to An Origin server it's a you know either a flash media server or wazo server there's a
bunch of software that they can use for that and so they figure out they can only support six connections for one
origin server obviously that's not going to be enough for the 1 million viewers that you need they also then said okay
well we can put a cache in front of it so the cash just saves those big four megabyte files and it sends them out
right so they can have 20 connections per cache node so then they said okay
well we can have two layers of cache nodes so that that expands things considerably
um also because it's a video stream it's a latency uh it's it's a application
that really depends on low latency right so when you're watching a stream you wanted to not have a lag time so it's
really important to distribute you know your uh your your instances for your stream all around the world because
you're gonna have viewers present this sort of thing all around the world and they also um reserved basically or they were going
to use one of our regions Us West one which is the one in North California for S3 capacity so they were going to get
static images eventually sent from the actual Rover they're going to save those static images in the S3 bucket in in S3
bucket in the west coast region so what that allows them to do is basically you know S3 one of the things you can do
with it is that you can host static assets on it such as images JavaScript CSS files so that way they didn't need
ec2 instance they didn't need any compute at all to just serve up the stat assets so that significantly made their
architecture way simpler then once they plan this out they had to really test it they had to ensure confidence that it
was going to work because again they didn't have a do-over so again they had two guys that worked
on this uh luckily one of them was a rocket scientist so you know when you have really talented staff that that
helps a lot too obviously and actually so quadrino works for Amazon web services
um and so the here's the actual architecture that they came up with so uh what this is is you have your actual
laptop that has you know your your video stream plugged into it so it had NASA TV streaming through it and it would send
it out to two Adobe Flash media servers so primary and a secondary so if the primary failed they could fail over to
the secondary and then that would get cached by two tiers of nginx caches so these were just um
nginx groups of nginx instances and this was spread around two different availability zones so it was architected
for high availability so if something happened to one availability Zone you would still have your secondary flash media server in an
availability another availability Zone and then there was an Amazon elastic load
balancer in front of it so with your actual uh stream could just point to one
of the elastic load balancers and get the video to the player so folks could
see it now they also did use cloudfront which is our content delivery network but they only used it for Museum
Partners so they had some museums around the world that you know had theaters that were showing this live stream and
so that's what it was used for now the really beautiful thing about this setup is that it's a cloud information stack
so what this means is they could spin up one of these called 42 packs because they had 42 instances in them so they
could spin up one of these on demand so you just take your class formation as our service that allows you to Define
you know your elastic load balancers and your instances or whatever artifacts you have in your AWS architecture and you
put in a file and you can deploy it off of that file so they could go and deploy
one of these 42 packs in any region that they wanted to based on their needs so if they you know during the live stream
decided oh I need more capacity they could just launch it and they had that capacity so
then they had to load test it so I've actually been doing a session on load testing tomorrow at 10 A.M so if you
want to find out you know more more in-depth information about load testing you can come to it but what they ended
up doing was they used the tool called soasta which is a third party load testing tool I think they have a booth
down in the Expo area and so they were testing it just to be safe as you can see there for 10 million users they just
wanted to be safe you know they were estimating one but they just did it times 10. and so what they were actually
testing for was bandwidth usage right so video streaming is all about just outgoing bandwidth and so you want to
make sure it supports the right levels of bandwidth so they'd spin on these Stacks up and then they would test it to
make to see if they got stable consistent bandwidth and you should be able to predict the bandwidth just based on how many instances they have they can
support you know a certain amount of connections I think it was 20 and so you have 42 instances so they wanted to make
sure that it lined up with their math and it did so uh what they saw was uh that they were
getting off of each one of these uh 42 packs they were getting 25 gigabits a second of uh bandwidth so every time
they launched one of these cloudformation templates they could get 25 gigabits more
so um then what they needed to test was is our
caching working right so you want that 25 gigabits to be coming out of your
actual uh your streaming your caching servers that are running engine you don't want them to hit your flash media
server because that's not going to have enough capacity to support that kind of bandwidth so what they then look for is
how much bandwidth is coming out of our flash media server into the caches and that was only 42 megabits a second so
it's a small fraction of the total bandwidth so that means their caching was actually working and it could sustain this level of
traffic so they ended up getting beautiful pictures and a live stream and
everything worked and it worked really well uh and so they're really happy with that now they learned some interesting
things from it they learned that testing delivers confidence so if they didn't
test us they would have had no idea going into the day that the Rover was Landing this was going to work or not
it's all theoretical so the fact that they tested it gave them a lot more confidence that this was actually going
to work they used the AWS cloud formation for it made their operations
really easy if they had to manually set up 42 instances every time they wanted capacity that would have taken a lot of
time that would have waste a lot of time time that they didn't have since they only had six days so they were able to
use cloudformation for for automatically spinning up their architecture they also learned that
you know you should really test thoroughly so we were talking about testing bandwidth but it's a thing that you don't test that uh that usually
breaks and so what happened in this case was you know they had a lot of capacity for their live stream but the actual
player that was hosting the video was hosted off a Content management system
that was on a really small instance with a really small RDS instance in one availability Zone it wasn't multisy so
had they not discovered that their stream would have been great but their player would have crashed and nobody would have seen the stream so it's good
that they went through and discovered that and upsized their uh their content management system as well they learned
that AWS Services can scale big uh you know if you think about it in six days they were able to create their own
essentially their own content delivery Network they were able to plan it and create it in only six days which is
amazing and small teams can scale big it doesn't matter you know how many servers you're operating on or what what it is
if you if you use Automation and proper deployment techniques you can scale really big with a really small team with
two people and so the other interesting thing about this was you know I told you they they
used the US West one for their S3 images so this was the actual first image that
